user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_file_tell:
```c
lfs_soff_t lfs_file_tell(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_file_tell(%p, %p)", (void*)lfs, (void*)file);
    LFS_ASSERT(lfs_mlist_isopen(lfs->mlist, (struct lfs_mlist*)file));

    lfs_soff_t res = lfs_file_tell_(lfs, file);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_file_tell -> %"PRId32, res);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return res;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_file_tell:
#define LFS_LOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg,0)
...
#define LFS_UNLOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg)
...
#define LFS_TRACE(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
#define LFS_ASSERT(test) assert(test)
...
static lfs_soff_t lfs_file_tell_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file) {
    (void)lfs;
    return file->pos;
}
...
static bool lfs_mlist_isopen(struct lfs_mlist *head,
        struct lfs_mlist *node) {
    for (struct lfs_mlist **p = &head; *p; p = &(*p)->next) {
        if (*p == (struct lfs_mlist*)node) {
            return true;
        }
    }

    return false;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected all provided fragments: lfs_file_tell, lfs_file_tell_, lfs_mlist_isopen, and the related macros (LFS_LOCK, LFS_UNLOCK, LFS_TRACE, LFS_ASSERT). None of these assign to any function parameter identifier (no occurrences of "lfs =", "file =", "head =", or "node ="), so no pointer parameter itself is being modified. The code only: - dereferences pointer parameters to read members (e.g., file->pos, lfs->mlist), which is permitted (the pointed-to object may be modified, but here it is only read), - casts parameters to void to silence unused warnings, - passes parameters to other functions or macros, - and in lfs_mlist_isopen takes the address of the local parameter head to create a local pointer-to-pointer (p) but never writes through p to modify head or node. The macros expand to expressions that do not alter their cfg/parameter arguments. Therefore there are no fragments that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in the supplied code.
